StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: In surveys of representative US municipal water supplies, ethylbenzene has been detected in most cases(1,2,4-8,10). Values for 3 New Orleans finished drinking waters ranged 1.6 to 2.3 ppb(6). Chicago Central Water Works on Lake Michigan measured 4 ppb(8). It has been found in the water supply for Evansville, IN on the Ohio River(7). 6 of 10 US cities were found to be positive(1,4). One US city had 1 of 4 samples pos with a 1 ppb average, while another reported no positive samples(5). Tap water from bank infiltrated Rhine River water in the Netherlands measured 30 ppb in one study(3). Zurich, Switzerland tap water - detected not quantified(9). 1982 US groundwater supply survey, random samples of finished water supplies using groundwater as a source, 466 random samples, 0.6%, pos (0.5 ppb detection limit), 0.8 ppb median, 1.1 ppb max(10). Ethylbenzene was detected 19% of 119 bottled drinking water samples collected in Kuwait at a mean concentration of 1.53 ug/L (range 0.10-5.17 ug/L)(11). A monitoring study of 954 community water systems in the US and Puerto Rico during 1999-2000 detected ethylbenzene (min detect limit 0.033 ug/L) in 0.5% of all samples(12). Drinking water collected from 1208 domestic wells between 1985-2002 had positive ethylbenzene detections in 8 samples(13).

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: Ethylbenzene has been detected but not quantified in a 1970-76 US survey(1,2). In 14 heavily industrialized US river basins, 5 of 204 sites were positive at 1-4 ppb; Chicago area and Illinois River Basin, 5 of 31 sites positive at 1-4 ppb(3). Two representative US cities, city A - 41% of 28 samples positive, 5.0 ppb average, city B - 40% of 48 samples positive 3.2 ppb average(4). Lower Tennessee River near Calvert City, KY reported 4.0 ppb ethylbenzene(5). Lake Michigan, Chicago Sanitary and Ship Channel measured 1-2 ppb(6). Ethylbenzene was detected but not quantified in the River Glatt, Switzerland(7). USEPA STORET database, 1,101 data points, 10% positive with a <5.0 ppb median(8).

Reference: (1) Dewulf J, Vanlangenhove H; Water Res 31: 1825-38 (1997)

StringWithMarkup.String: SEAWATER: Ethylbenzene concentrations were found to be 30-50 ng/L in an estuary in Brazos, US; between <10-46.3 ng/L in UK; and 36.9 ng/L in Belgium(1). Ethylbenzene has been found in concentrations of 4.5-30 ng/L in Vineyard Sound; 0.4-4.5 ng/L in coastal and shelf sea water in the Gulf of Mexico; 5.5-22 ng/L in the coastal waters of Spain; 4.3-380 ng/L in Campeche Shelf; <10 ng/L in shelf and bay waters in UK; and 9.4-18.7 ng/L in Belgian Continental Shelf(1). Ethylbenzene mean concentration of 21.94 ng/L was found in the South Northern sea up to 60 km offshore in the Scheldt Estuary(2). In the coastal waters off the western Gulf of Mexico at the mouth of the Brazos River, TX, ethylbenzene concentrations ranged between 0.004-0.5 ug/L(3). In the Gulf of Mexico in unpolluted areas ethylbenzene concentrations wss 0.4 to 5 ppb(4,6), while an area of anthropogenic influence ranged from 5 to 15 ppb(6). Cape Cod, MA measured ethylbenzene at 22 ppb(5,7) with 11 ppb being average(5). In the coastal waters of the Dutch Northern Sea, 108 samples ranged from not detected to 20 parts per trillion and averaged 4 parts per trillion(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW: Rain water collected in West Los Angeles, CA in March 1982 contained an ethylbenzene concentration of 9 ng/L(1). Snow and ice samples collected directly in cloud in 2005 and 2006 at Jungfraujoch, Germany contained mean ethylbenzene levels ranging from 74-285 ng/L(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Industries with mean raw wastewater concentrations of ethylbenzene >2000 ppb included: gum and wood chemicals (11,000 ppb), pharmaceutical manufacturing (10,000 ppb), paint and ink formulation, and auto and other laundries(1). Effluents from representative water treatment plants in Southern California were variable <10 ppb at San Diego City to 130 ppb at Los Angeles Co (both measurements following primary treatment)(2); <10 ppb detected following secondary treatment(2). In a US city survey, 17% of 6 samples were positive for ethylbenzene at a 6.0 ppb average(3), Lake Michigan, North Side sewage treatment plant was 1 ppb(4). USEPA STORET database, 1,368 data points, 7.4% positive for ethylbenzene with a <3.0 ppb median(5). MN municipal solid waste landfills, leachates, 6 sites, 100% positive at 12-820 ppb, contaminated groundwater (by inorganic indices), 13 sites, 61.5% positive at 1.2-590 ppb, other groundwater (apparently not contaminated as indicated by inorganic indices), 7 sites, 14.3% positive, 9.4 ppb average(6). An estimated 18.0 and 12.28 kilotons of ethylbenzene was emitted as part of gasoline exhaust emissions from motor vehicles in 1987 and 1990, respectively in UK(7). Based on 2004 monitoring in tunnels in Sao Paulo, Brazil, the average entire fleet emission factor for ethylbenzene was estimated to be 31.1 mg/kg fuel burned(8). Ethylbenzene is emitted in the exhaust from heavy-duty diesel engines(9). Ethylbenzene was detected in the odor emissions from a biological treatment plant for municipal solid waste in China(10).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Pre-1981 ethylbenezene concentrations for major western US cities ranged from 0.1 to 27.7 ppb(1-5), with an average of 2.68 ppb(SRC). Representative centers in New Jersey had a range of 0.17 to 0.33 ppb average with 107 of 110 samples positive in the summer of 1981(6). Ethylbenzene was detected but not quantified in another 1981 New Jersey study(7). Ethylbenzene has been detected in 6 USSR cities, including Lenningrad as well as New York and Paris in 1976(8-10). Concentrations detected at The Hague, Netherlands were 5 ppb(11), in Sidney Australia 1.3 ppb(12), in Japan 0.2 ppb, and Frankfurt-am-Main, Germany 1 ppb(13). Three sites in England away from traffic measured 16.1 to 18.8 parts/trillion average, while 2 sites with heavy traffic 28.7 to 33.9 parts/trillion average(14). An ethylbenzene concentration of 8.7 ppb was measured in the atmosphere of Zurich, Switzerland(15). A total 669 air samples from the US (pre-1982) had a median ethylbenzene concentrations of 1.2 ppb(16). Gas-phase concentration of ethylbenzene during 7 rain events, Portland, OR, Feb-Apri 1984 found 100% positive detections with a range of 780-2800 ng/cu m and a 1300 ng/cu m average(17). Concentraion at Exhibition Road, London, May-Aug 1983, 267 samples, 100% pos, 0.05-2.17 ppb, 0.78 ppb average(18); June-July 1982, 256 samples, not detected-3.3 ppb, 0.88 ppb average(19). US 1979-1984, 15 cities sampled with 1-2 weeks of sampling/site, overall range, not detected-31.5 ppb; range of average, 0.6-4-6 ppb, average of average, 1.9 ppb(20). Ethylbenzene in outdoor air concentrations in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in December 1995 ranged from 3.1-7.4 ug/cu m(21).

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: Ethylbenzene indoor air concentrations at an office builiding in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in Dec 1995 ranged from 9.3-13.1 ug/cu m(1). Samples from 36 Chicago metropolitan area homes tested showed a 57% detection frequency in indoor air(2). Median concentrations of 0.3 to 1.0 ug/cu m were detected during the winter and spring of 2000 in indoor air samples in inner-city schools in Minneapolis, MN(3). Monitoring of air inside of buses and bus stations in Hangzhou, China during 2007-2008 detected mean ethylbenzene concentrations of 7.1 and 2.9 ug/cu m respectively(4). Indoor air samples collected at a variety of micro-environments in Boston MA in 2004 and 2005 detected geometric mean ethylbenzene levels of 4.04 and 1.90 ug/cu m in stores and dining facilities respectively(5). Monitoring of air inside of public buses in northern Spain in 2007 detected median and mean ethylbenzene levels of 0.97 and 1.30 ug/cu m respectively(6). The mean ethylbenzene concentration inside patrol vehicles was 0.9 ppb while the ambient air outside was 0.1 ppb(7). Monitoring at 100 residential homes in New Jersey between 2003-2006 detected mean and maximum ethylbenzene concentrations of 3.72 and 39 ug/cu m(8). The indoor air of 37 small and medium-sized commercial buildings in California had a geometric mean ethylbenzene level of 0.62 ug/cu m(9).

StringWithMarkup.String: Ethylbenzene has been detected in tobacco smoke, tobacco substitute smoke and in tobacco(1). The mean ethylbenzene concentration at premises in Spain allowing smoking, not-allowing smoking and general outdoor air was 2.3, 1.1 and 0.6 ug/cu m respectively(2). StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 201,833 workers (34,405 of these are female) are potentially exposed to ethylbenzene in the US(1). Occupational exposure to ethylbenzene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where ethylbenzene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to ethylbenzene via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing ethylbenzene(SRC). The general population can be exposed to ethylbenzene via inhalation especially in cities near many factories and heavily traveled highways and from air from burning gas, oil and coal(2). Ethylbenzene is infrequently detected in private and public groundwater wells used for drinking water(2). Higher levels of ethylbenzene may be found in private residential wells near landfills, waste sites, or leaking underground fuel storage tanks(2). People with ethylbenzene-contaminated tap water could be exposed by drinking the water or eating foods prepared with it(2). Exposure to ethylbenzene may occur by using any of the following products: gasoline, carpet glues, varnishes and paints, tobacco products and automotive products(2). Ethylbenzene air concentrations of 78,000-178,000 ug/cu m have been monitored at municipal waste composting facilities(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Exposure assessment for children found that inhalation of ethylbenzene exceeded ingestion, urban exposures exceed rural/suburban exposures, and exposures of children ages 0-2 years old exceed those of children from age 3 to 19(1). The highest "central tendency" estimated intake was for bottle-fed infants <1 year old in an urban, smoking setting (3.63X10-3 mg/kg bwt/day total; 2.64X10-3 mg/kg bwt/day from inhalation, 9.90X10-4 mg/kg bwt/day from diet). The highest "upper-bound" intake estimate was for an ethylbenzene production worker's breastfed child (8.10X10-3 mg/kg bwt/day total; 5.87X10-3 mg/kg bwt/day from inhalation, 1.70X10-3 mg/kg bwt/day from breast feeding and 5.32X10-4 mg/kg bwt/day from diet)(1).

The NLM Curated PubMed Citations section links to all PubMed records that are tagged with the same MeSH term that has been associated with a particular compound.

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts.
